climbs.name: The Unhedral (aka Ladybug)
climbs.fa: NM 2020; first developed by Tom and Tyler

content.description:
Twenty-five feet of jumbled moderate climbing to a ledge is followed by twenty feet of thrutching in a stellar bulbous finger to hands to wide crack.  After sorting out the overhanging section (height dependent), an awkward hand, a key ring lock, and thoughtful feet will move you through the crux to an amazing hand jam that unlocks the rest of the route.  Finish at the ledge.  If desired, add a little spice by slinging the anchor long and trending left to another short finger crack that ends atop the boulder.  Tackle The Unhedral.

 First cleaned up, TR'd by Tyler and Tom.
content.protection: Single rack 0.4-#2 +/- a few medium nuts sews it up.  Anchor hangers, no rings.
content.location: Not actually on the same formation as Inversion Wall, but adjacent to it.  Head climber's left from Aretection about 100 feet along the trail.  Look up to locate the obvious finger crack moving over a bulge.

content.description:
An amazing finger crack in a dihedral that you will wish was longer!

 Look for this iconic arching left facing dihedral at the Inversion Wall. The climbing is hard as soon as you start and doesn't really let up. Tech your way up the corner placing small gear to a set of anchors. There is a fixed piece in the middle that is presumably from the FA party. The upper finger crack stays wet for a couple of days after a rain.
content.protection: Purple Mastercam to 0.5 camalot. Extra thin finger pieces will make you feel happy.
content.location: It is pretty obvious when you are at the Inversion Wall.

content.description: Climb a lieback seam past some gear to the first bolt.  Make big long moves up the arete past bolts to a tree anchor.
content.protection: A medium cam or so, bolts, tree anchor.
content.location: Look for the bolted arete up the Inversion Wall...next to the thin finger crack "Dihedral"

content.description: This is a small wall with two classic trad climbs named because the two climbs are the inverse of each other. The Dihedral shouldn't be missed. The wall faces SW and is a good place to start on warmer days or finish on colder days.
